misconceptions.name: Implemented road trip cost calculator instead of number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to repeatedly compute and sum driving costs for road trips, rather than implementing the required number guessing game with a random secret number, repeated guesses, and high/low feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates and accumulates the cost of driving trips, stopping based on a condition on the cost.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should implement a number guessing game: generate a random number between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess, and after each wrong guess indicate whether it is too high or too low, terminating only when the correct number is guessed and then reporting how many guesses it took.
symptoms: Class and prompts refer to driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of guessing a number.
No use of Random or generation of a secret number between 1 and 100.
Loop is used to repeatedly read trip parameters and break on an odd cost, rather than looping on user guesses until the correct answer.
No conditional logic comparing a user guess to a secret number to output "Too high" or "Too low".
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a completely different exercise (road trip cost) instead of the specified number guessing game, suggesting confusion about the assignment requirements or mixing up files between questions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm directly from the requirements: 1) create a Random object and generate a number in [1, 100]; 2) use a loop that keeps asking for guesses; 3) inside the loop, compare the guess to the secret number and print "Too high" or "Too low" accordingly; 4) when the guess is correct, exit the loop and print how many guesses were taken.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompts, and logic clearly solve a road trip cost problem and there is no trace of random number generation, guessing, or high/low feedback as required by the assignment.

evidence.note: All variables, prompts, and logic are about computing and summing driving costs; there is no random number, guessing input, or high/low feedback as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Using string format specifier %s to print double values
misconceptions.description: The student uses the %s format specifier in printf when printing double values, relying on implicit conversion instead of using a numeric format specifier like %f.
misconceptions.student_belief: The %s placeholder in printf can be used to print any type of value, including doubles, and is an acceptable way to format numeric output.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java's printf, %s is the string format specifier and is intended for strings (or objects converted via toString). Floating-point numbers should be printed with %f or related numeric specifiers (e.g., %.2f to control decimal places). While %s may work by auto-boxing and calling toString, it is not the intended or precise way to format numeric values.
symptoms: Double variables cost and totalCost are printed using %s instead of a numeric format specifier.
Output format for doubles is left to the default toString representation, without explicit control over decimal places.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about Java's printf format specifiers, or the assumption that %s is a generic placeholder like in some other formatting systems.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review Java's printf format specifiers. When printing doubles, use %f (e.g., "%.2f") instead of %s. For example: System.out.printf("The cost of driving is $%.2f%n", cost);
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student consistently uses %s for both cost and totalCost, suggesting a patterned misconception about format specifiers rather than an isolated typo.

evidence.note: Both printf calls use %s to print double values (cost and totalCost), indicating the student is not using the appropriate numeric format specifier like %f.

misconceptions.task: Generating random number (1-100), Loop for guessing (while/do-while), Logic for "Too high" hint, Logic for "Too low" hint, specific termination condition (correct guess)
misconceptions.name: Complete Failure to Address Prompt
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (a road trip cost calculator) instead of the required Number Guessing Game. None of the required components—random number generation, guessing loop, or conditional feedback logic—are implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied or submitted code intended for a completely different assignment, believing this submission would fulfill the requirements for the Number Guessing Game, or they fundamentally misunderstood the requirement to a severe degree.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must utilize the 'Random' class to generate a secret number, employ a loop to repeatedly prompt for and read integer guesses, and use conditional statements (if/else if) to provide 'Too high,' 'Too low,' or 'Correct' feedback.
symptoms: Code file name and class name ('RoadTripCost') are unrelated to the problem.
Program prompts for distance, MPG, and price inputs.
Calculates cost using floating-point arithmetic.
Loop termination is based on the parity of the calculated cost's integer value.
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or catastrophic misinterpretation of the task requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement carefully and submit the program that implements the Number Guessing Game. Ensure your code includes random number generation and appropriate looping and conditional logic for guessing.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is demonstrably for a different problem, making this a confirmed failure to meet the requirements of the prompt.

evidence.note: The class name indicates an entirely different program subject.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("Enter the driving distance in miles: ");
evidence.note: The program prompts for inputs related to the road trip calculation, not number guessing.
The core logic and termination condition are focused on calculating cost and breaking on an odd cost, not comparing a guess to a target number.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator with a sentinel-controlled loop instead of a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user repeatedly guesses until correct with "Too high" / "Too low" feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that repeatedly asks for driving distance, miles per gallon, and gas price to compute trip cost, accumulating a total until some stopping condition (here, when the integer part of the cost is odd).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should be a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100 using Random, repeatedly read the user's integer guess in a loop, print "Too high" or "Too low" after each incorrect guess, and terminate only when the user guesses the secret number, then report how many guesses it took.
symptoms: Class is named RoadTripCost rather than something related to a guessing game.
Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon, not for a guessed number between 1 and 100.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No logic that compares a guess to a secret answer or prints "Too high" / "Too low".
Loop termination is based on the parity of the integer part of the cost (and a cost==0 continue), not on correctly guessing a secret number.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or ignoring the problem specification, or reusing code from a different assignment, indicating difficulty in mapping a word problem to the required program behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and list the required behaviors in plain English first (generate secret number, loop reading guesses, compare and give feedback, count guesses, stop on correct guess). Then translate that step-by-step into code using Random, a while or do-while loop, and if/else conditions for "Too high" / "Too low".
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is devoted to computing and accumulating driving costs; there is no trace of random numbers, guessing logic, or high/low feedback, so the implementation clearly does not target the described number guessing game.

evidence.note: Entire program is a road trip cost calculator with distance/mpg/price prompts and a loop controlled by cost parity, with no random number, no guessing input, and no high/low feedback, which does not match the required number guessing game behavior.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard for the problem statement
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a completely different programming problem (calculating road trip cost) instead of the requested Number Guessing Game. None of the required features (random number generation, guessing loop, comparison logic) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either copied and pasted the wrong file, confused the assignment requirements, or intentionally submitted a non-related solution, believing they could repurpose some element (like input reading) but ultimately failing to address the core problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must implement the Number Guessing Game as described in the problem statement.
symptoms: Code implements road trip cost calculation.
Program's purpose is entirely different from the prompt.
Missing required concepts like Random number generation and comparison logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misidentification of the required file/task, or a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment’s requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement for Q2 carefully and ensure the submitted code addresses the Number Guessing Game, including random number generation, user input loops, and conditional logic for 'Too high/low' hints.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student's code is irrelevant to the prompt and receives 0 points across all rubric tasks.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem domain.
This arithmetic operation calculates cost based on external inputs (distance, mpg, price), which is unrelated to a guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Using cost calculation result parity for loop termination
misconceptions.description: The student uses a complex, non-sensical termination condition: checking if the integer part of the calculated 'cost' is odd. If the truncated integer cost is odd, the loop breaks. This is highly unlikely to result in the road trip cost calculation performing correctly, and certainly irrelevant to a guessing game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to think that the required logic for determining when to stop (a correct guess in the original problem) can be replaced by an arbitrary mathematical condition applied to intermediate results, perhaps as a placeholder or a confused attempt at conditional flow control.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Loop termination should be based on the user's guess matching the secret number, not on conditional logic involving unrelated arithmetic results.
symptoms: Use of modulus operator (%) on a truncated double value.
Loop stops randomly based on input values, not a matching condition.
misconceptions.root_cause: Attempting to force fit complex, unrelated logic to fulfill the requirement for a termination condition, possibly confusing this with an entry/exit flag.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: When designing a loop for a guessing game, the loop control structure must check if the user's guess equals the computer's answer. This condition determines whether the loop continues or breaks.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The `if (((int) cost) % 2 != 0) {break;}` construct serves as the primary exit condition for the infinite loop (`for (;;)`) and is erroneous both for the code's current purpose and the intended problem.

evidence.note: This complex condition is used for loop termination, checking if the integer part of 'cost' is odd, which is completely irrelevant to the guessing game's termination condition of matching the secret number.

misconceptions.name: Wrong program submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a Road Trip Cost Calculator instead of implementing a Number Guessing Game. This indicates either a submission error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file or does not understand that they were supposed to implement a guessing game rather than a cost calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a Number Guessing Game where: (1) computer generates random 1-100, (2) user guesses repeatedly, (3) program gives 'Too high'/'Too low' hints, (4) program terminates when guess is correct, (5) final message shows guess count.
symptoms: Code calculates trip cost instead of playing a guessing game
No random number generation
No comparison of guess to secret number
No 'Too high' or 'Too low' logic
Program terminates on odd cost value, not correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Either a copy-paste/wrong file submission error, or the student did not carefully read or understand the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Implement from scratch: (1) create Random object and generate secret 1-100, (2) use while loop for guesses, (3) use if/else to compare guess to secret and print hints, (4) break when guess equals secret, (5) count and report guesses.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete certainty – the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap in logic or intent with the Number Guessing Game requirements.

evidence.note: Class name is 'RoadTripCost' and the program requests driving distance, MPG, and price per gallon – completely different from guessing game requirements.
Calculates trip cost and breaks on odd cost value – completely unrelated to checking if a guess is correct.
